Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Support multiple Mono Archive packages" (#3105) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Mono BCL assemblies are now built to specifically target a concrete
platform/operating system and thus they cannot be shared freely between
different operating systems. This creates a problem for the Xamarin.Android
designer which needs to run Xamarin.Android on the *desktop* machine, to render
the application UI. The issue here is that, e.g., `mscorlib.dll` which was
shipped with Xamarin.Android targetted Android/Unix instead of Windows and,
thus, could not be loaded by the designer causing a crash.

This patch implements download and use of the per-OS Mono archives containing
the system specific BCL assemblies for both Unix and Windows hosts. After
downloading both the host archive (e.g. Darwin or Linux) and the Windows
archive, the files are placed in different directories under Xamarin.Android
installation root (`bcl/` for Windows, and `$HOST_OS/bcl` for Unix) thus making
it possible for the designer to load assemblies appropriate for the host system.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] don't copy to linksrc for Debug builds" (#3044) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
While investigating performance of the `_LinkAssembliesNoShrink`
MSBuild target, I noticed it has the following behavior:

* Take all assemblies from `@(ResolvedAssemblies)`. These are their
  original locations from after `Build`. Some from `bin\Debug`, some
  from `$(UserProfile)\.nuget`, etc.
* Output assemblies directly to be packaged, in:
  `$(IntermediateOutputPath)android\assets`

After a build, however, there was a `linksrc` directory containing all
assemblies. For the Xamarin.Forms app in this repo, it was ~69.7MB and
had 77 files.

But this directory appears to be completely unused when
`$(AndroidLinkMode)` is `None`?

That means we could skip a few MSBuild targets in this case:

* `_CopyIntermediateAssemblies`
* `_CopyPdbFiles`
* `_CopyMdbFiles`

An initial build of the Xamarin.Forms project in this repo used to
take:

     16 ms  _CopyMdbFiles                              1 calls
     77 ms  _CopyPdbFiles                              1 calls
    202 ms  _CopyIntermediateAssemblies                1 calls

So this looks like it saves ~275ms on debug builds. I suspect the
savings would be even better on slower machines (or without SSDs).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "EditText text is not aligned to the center properly while changing the layout of the View." (#3093) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run the attached sample.
2. Click the "Change Layout " button.
3. Text is not aligned to the center of the layout.

<!--
[App13.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3178280/App13.zip)

-->

### Expected Behavior
Text should be aligned to center of the View, as the layout changes.

### Actual Behavior
Text is not aligned to center of the View, as the layout changes.

### Version Information
MicroSoft visual studio Version 15.9.4
Xamarin Android sdk 9.1.4.2

Reproduced in android device with version 7.1

[App13.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3178309/App13.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Marshal.StructureToPtr freeze with STRUCTs containing float[] arrays" (#3101) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a STRUCT with this particulare shape:
```
[StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential, Pack = 1)]
        public struct RECORD
        {
            public byte reset;
            [MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.ByValArray, SizeConst = 2)]
            public float[] refO2;
            public float ratio;
        }
```
2. Try to marshal the STRUCT
```
RECORD rec = new RECORD();
            int size = Marshal.SizeOf<RECORD>();
            byte[] raw = new byte[size];

            IntPtr ptr = Marshal.AllocHGlobal(size);

                Marshal.StructureToPtr<RECORD>(rec, ptr, true);
             
                //In RELEASE mode this point is never reached
``` 


[MarshalStruct2ptrFreeze.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3191602/MarshalStruct2ptrFreeze.zip)

### Expected Behavior

Marshal.StructureToPtr<RECORD>(rec, ptr, true); sould not freeze

### Actual Behavior

Marshal.StructureToPtr<RECORD>(rec, ptr, true); never exit

### Version Information

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[java-runtimes] Set `%JAVA_HOME%`" (#3104) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
For some unknown reason, the JDK environment on @jonpryor's Windows
machine is "wonky," in that the `src\java-runtimes` directory fails
to build because the Android SDK `dx` command fails to execute
because `dx` cannot find Java:

	> cd src\java-runtimes
	> msbuild
	...
	ERROR: No suitable Java found. In order to properly use the Android Developer
	Tools, you need a suitable version of Java JDK installed on your system.
	We recommend that you install the JDK version of JavaSE, available here:
	  http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads

	If you already have Java installed, you can define the JAVA_HOME environment
	variable in Control Panel / System / Avanced System Settings to point to the
	JDK folder.

	You can find the complete Android SDK requirements here:
	  http://developer.android.com/sdk/requirements.html

This happens when:

 1. `%JAVA_HOME%` refers to a non-existent directory.
    (*How* @jonpryor got an invalid directory in there...)  *or*

 2. `%JAVA_HOME%` is empty and `$(JavaSdkDirectory)` refers to a
    *valid* directory.

(Again, why this happens to @jonpryor but not others on the team has
not yet been determined.)

Fix this by explicitly providing `%JAVA_HOME%` within the `<Exec/>`
task which executes `dx`, so that `java` can be found.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Garbage data when marshalling an array" (#3100) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a STRUCT that contains a float[] field: (or a int[] field)
```
[StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential, Pack = 1)]
public struct RECORD
{
    public byte tag;
    [MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.ByValArray, SizeConst = 4)]
    public float[] refs;
}
```
2. Marshal the structure to a pointer and print the raw data:
```
            RECORD rec = new RECORD();
            int size = Marshal.SizeOf<RECORD>();
            byte[] raw = new byte[size];
            IntPtr ptr = Marshal.AllocHGlobal(size);
            Marshal.StructureToPtr<RECORD>(rec, ptr, true);
            Marshal.Copy(ptr, raw, 0, size);
            //raw should be all zeroed
```
3. The raw data sould be all zero, but it contains garbage data.

This is a demo.
[FloatMarshalFails.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3191218/FloatMarshalFails.zip)


### Expected Behavior

The byte[] array of the marshaled STRUCT should be all zeros

### Actual Behavior

The bytes in the array where should be the float[] fields contains garbage data

### Version Information

1. On macOS and within Visual Studio, select Visual Studio > About Visual Studio, then click the Show Details button, then click the Copy Information button.

2. Paste below this comment block.
-->

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "String.MissingMethod exception occurs while using String.Split method" (#3078) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

Hi Team,

We at Syncfusion develop data visualization controls for Xamarin and we have more than 90 controls spread across all platforms of Xamarin. Please refer the below link for a description about us.
UserGuide: https://help.syncfusion.com/xamarin/sfdatagrid/overview
FeatureTour: https://www.syncfusion.com/products/xamarin.

We would like to bring to your notice a bug that we encountered as follows.

I have a custom Android library project which has split method as follows.

namespace CustomAndLibrary   
{ 
    public static class CustomStringSplit     
     {
         public static void Split(string s,char c)         
          {              
                 s.Split(c);       
          }    
      } 
}

The above project is built in a machine which has **.Net Core** installed in it.

Now i am referring the above split method in an Android application in another machine which does not have NetCore installed by referring the CustomAndLibrary Dll. While referring it “String.MissingMethod Exception” occurs. 

namespace StringSplitExp
{
    [Activity(Label = "StringSplitExp", MainLauncher = true, Icon = "@mipmap/icon")]
    public class MainActivity : Activity
    {
        string name = "Sync";
        TextView label;

        protected override void OnCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState)
        {
            base.OnCreate(savedInstanceState);

            label = new TextView(this);
            label.Text = name;


            CustomAndLibrary.CustomStringSplit.Split(name, 'c');

            // Set our view from the "main" layout resource
            SetContentView(label);                      
        }
    }
}

--

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run the sample
2. Note String.Missing method exception occurs in the sample link.

### Expected Behavior

Exception should not occur.

### Actual Behavior

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: Issue occurs in machine in which Netcore is not installed.

While getting method declaration information for **String.Split method ** from .Netcore installed machine, I get the below information.

public String[] Split(char separator, StringSplitOptions options = StringSplitOptions.None);


On the other hand, if get the method declaration information for**String.Split method ** from a machine where .Netcore is not installed, I get the below information.

Public string[] Split (params char[] separator); 

The Api information in the below link:
**Xamarin.Android:** https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.string.split?view=xamarinandroid-7.1

**.Net core :** https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.string.split?view=netcore-3.0#System_String_Split_System_Char_System_Int32_System_StringSplitOptions_

### Screenshots

Exception Screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31398953/57277869-a6728480-70c2-11e9-82b6-c90c9a792ca4.png)


### Reproduction Link

You can download the CustomAndLibrary and sample in the below link.
Librabry project link: http://www.syncfusion.com/downloads/support/directtrac/general/ze/CustomAndLibrary-2090802213

Sample link: http://www.syncfusion.com/downloads/support/directtrac/general/ze/StringSplitExp268735194

I have also attached the Mscorlib Dll for your reference.
MsCorlib dll: http://www.syncfusion.com/downloads/support/directtrac/general/ze/Mscorlib_Dll1940088283

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[build] Allow Windows to override `$(JavaSdkDirectory)`" (#3103) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Allow `$(JavaSdkDirectory)` to be specified within
`Configuration.Override.props` to control the JDK location.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug] [UWP] ListView renders very slowly on UWP when in a Grid or StackLayout" (#6233) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

If a simple ListView is inside of a Grid or StackLayout, it renders very slowly and you can see black area slowly uncover the ListView.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open attached sample
2. Run on UWP in Debug (Issue is most pronounced in Debug, but is visible in release as well)

### Expected Behavior
ListView should appear with no visible loading

### Actual Behavior
ListView appears all black at first and slowly ListView is shown

## Notes
Test project uses a StackLayout as the top level layout. Swap with a Grid and the behavior is the same. 

Remove the StackLayout and the issue goes away. 

Issue is most pronounced when debugging, but is still noticeable in a Release build. 

I know having a single child of a StackLayout or a Grid is not good practice, but the issue persists if I add other controls to the StackLayout or Grid, and certainly it should be OK to have a ListView inside a Grid or StackLayout. I did not test other layout types, but I suspect the issue would remain. 

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.6 and 4.0.pre-10
- Last known good version: unknown
- IDE: VS 2019
- Platform Target Frameworks: 
  
  - UWP:   17763

### Screenshots

[ListViewSlowRender.mp4.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/3200515/ListViewSlowRender.mp4.zip)


### Reproduction Link

[ListViewSlowUWP.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/3200516/ListViewSlowUWP.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[iOS] Can not load images from ios class library" (#6231) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
My Xamarin.Forms iOS project references an iOS lib that contains images and other stuffs, When I set Image Control's Source property to some image file from my iOS lib, the image is not displayed.

Based on the similar question on stack overflow https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32566167/xamarin-how-to-load-image-from-ios-library-project

Xamarin.Forms/Xamarin.Forms.Platform.iOS/Renderers/ImageRenderer.cs Line 132
`image = File.Exists(file) ? new UIImage(file) : UIImage.FromBundle(file);`

I assume it is because Xamarin.Forms is using UIImage.FromBundle(file) to convert file to image?
Can we provide a way to use UIImage.FromFile method to load images?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a iOS lib and reference to startup iOS project
2. Throw some images in to iOS lib
3. Create an image control and set the source property to the image from iOS library. 

### Expected Behavior
Image should be displayed.

### Actual Behavior
Nothing displayed.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.6.0.344457
- Last known good version: 3.6.0.293080
- IDE: Visual Studio 2019
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS:  11.2

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[CFUrl] Fix leaks of CFUrl instances." (#6090) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody: Create methods give ownership of the object, so in this case, owns=true. Prevents leak of CFUrl

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix ownership of CFSocketCreateRunLoopSource" (#6089) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Opened pull request "[CFNetwork] Fix ownership rules of CFHTTPAuthentication" (#6088) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody: `Create` methods give ownership of the object, so in this case, owns=true. Prevents leak of CFHTTPAuthentication

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[XHarness] Remove the old style bcl tests." (#6083) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody: Remove all the old style bcl tests but the mscorlib ones since they are not yet running properly on Mac OS X.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "MSBuild warning for headless AudioUnit extension" (#6087) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- 🚨 STOP 🚨 𝗦𝗧𝗢𝗣 🚨 𝑺𝑻𝑶𝑷 🚨 -->

<!--
Please fill in the *entire* template below.
The template is designed to avoid unnecessary delays to confirm and fix reported issues. Issues with missing information generally end up with a `need-info` label and take significantly more time to fix. Please help us help you!
For more information see https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-&-Suggestions
For support requests use https://www.xamarin.com/support
-->

AudioUnit app extensions with no UI can have an NSExtensionPointIdentifier of 'com.apple.AudioUnit', but this logs a warning from the ValidateAppBundleTaskBase.cs task.

See table 6-2 here: 
https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/General/Conceptual/ExtensibilityPG/AudioUnit.html

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Change the NSExtensionPointIdentifier of an AudioUnit extension from 'com.apple.AudioUnit-UI' to 'com.apple.AudioUnit'
2. Build


### Expected Behavior
No MSBuild warning

### Actual Behavior
MSBuild warning /Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/External/xbuild/Xamarin/iOS/Xamarin.iOS.Common.targets(3,3): Warning: The App Extension 'headlessAu' has an unrecognized NSExtensionPointIdentifier value ('com.apple.AudioUnit').

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Bump mono." (#6085) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
New commits in mono/mono:

* mono/mono@1ce13bb09d4 [arm] one more attempt to fix slotsize issue on llvmonly (#14444) (#14535)
* mono/mono@bb3c9db4976 [2019-02] [monodroid] Introduce 'win32 host' BCL build (#14504)
* mono/mono@ca17767758c [sdks] Set PATH in Android Windows SDK pipeline job (#14519)
* mono/mono@1cb80e7ecfc [sdks] Set win-amd64 CI_TAGS for windows pipeline step (#14516)
* mono/mono@c857c27d2e5 [2019-02][sdks] Build Android SDK on Windows (#14472)
* mono/mono@ab378434b96 [2019-02][ci] Add Android Windows (Release) archive job to pipeline (#14503)
* mono/mono@06c3f553122 [sdks] Lipo arm64_32 binaries for watchOS
* mono/mono@0f69e271534 [sdks] Use -pathmap CSC option for iOS/Mac
* mono/mono@69fae70242e [WinForms] Related Forms closing issue (#13717)
* mono/mono@4fa246df3f9 [2019-02] [WinForms] fix EditingCellFormattedValue getter and setter for bool value (#14437)
* mono/mono@a55d1c93771 [2019-02] TextInfo.ChangeCase should not use CultureInfo.CurrentCulture (#14438)
* mono/mono@b41578079ec [2019-02] Revert "[System] Add FSEvent FileSystemWatcher to monotouch BCL profile" (#14448)
* mono/mono@09429597dcb [metadata] use handle stack in mono_runtime_object_init_handle (#14445)
* mono/mono@77ddc3abc18 [arm64] set MONO_ARCH_HAVE_UNWIND_BACKTRACE for watch4 (#14452)
* mono/mono@f1aa58d9a90 [2019-02] Do not allocate handles in ReleaseMutex. (#14428)
* mono/mono@382c836e7fb Mutex memory leak on sgen GC (nursery, major).
* mono/mono@6ab15f25295 Usually do not create a handle in mono_runtime_invoke_handle. (#14423)
